CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: Although the non-fullerene PSC exhibits a lower PCE than the PC71BM - based device , the promising photovoltaic performance over 4% PCE with decent photovoltaic parameters ( V OC , J SC and FF ) suggests that PTATDPP can be used as a universal donor material compatible with various electron acceptors for high performance PSCs . We have designed and synthesized two anthracene - based low band - gap copolymers , PTATDPP and PTAFDPP. Since the TA unit has a highly conjugated 2-D structure with a weak electron - donating nature , the copolymer composed of TA and DPP units shows a relatively low band - gap , a low - lying HOMO energy level , high crystallinity , and efficient charge transporting characteristics. The PSCs fabricated from PTATDPP and PTAFDPP with PC71BM exhibit PCEs as high as 7.02% and 5.22% , respectively. Furthermore , PTATDPP shows a promising PCE of 4.23% when a non-fullerene acceptor ( di-PBI ) is used as an electron acceptor material for the PSC device. These results not only demonstrate that thienyl-substituted anthracene is a very promising building block as an electron - donating unit of low band - gap polymers for high performance PSCs but also PTATDPP can be used as a universal electron donor material compatible with various electron acceptor materials in PSCs.

Let's think step by step.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PTATDPP |
| PTAFDPP |
| PC71BM |
| di-PBI |

Note:

* PTATDPP and PTAFDPP are the names of the two anthracene-based low band-gap copolymers designed and synthesized in the study.
* PC71BM is the name of the non-fullerene electron acceptor material used in the PSC devices.
* di-PBI is the name of the non-fullerene acceptor material used as an electron acceptor in the PSC device fabricated from PTATDPP.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Material name" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PTATDPP |
| PTAFDPP |
| PC71BM |

Note:

* PTATDPP and PTAFDPP are the names of the two anthracene-based low band-gap copolymers designed and synthesized in the study.
* PC71BM is the name of the non-fullerene electron acceptor material used in the PSC devices.

The entities "di-PBI" and "thienyl-substituted anthracene" do not clearly refer to material names and have been removed from the list.

PV.content:
Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Value". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: Although the non-fullerene PSC exhibits a lower PCE than the PC71BM - based device , the promising photovoltaic performance over 4% PCE with decent photovoltaic parameters ( V OC , J SC and FF ) suggests that PTATDPP can be used as a universal donor material compatible with various electron acceptors for high performance PSCs . We have designed and synthesized two anthracene - based low band - gap copolymers , PTATDPP and PTAFDPP. Since the TA unit has a highly conjugated 2-D structure with a weak electron - donating nature , the copolymer composed of TA and DPP units shows a relatively low band - gap , a low - lying HOMO energy level , high crystallinity , and efficient charge transporting characteristics. The PSCs fabricated from PTATDPP and PTAFDPP with PC71BM exhibit PCEs as high as 7.02% and 5.22% , respectively. Furthermore , PTATDPP shows a promising PCE of 4.23% when a non-fullerene acceptor ( di-PBI ) is used as an electron acceptor material for the PSC device. These results not only demonstrate that thienyl-substituted anthracene is a very promising building block as an electron - donating unit of low band - gap polymers for high performance PSCs but also PTATDPP can be used as a universal electron donor material compatible with various electron acceptor materials in PSCs.

Let's think step by step.

| Property Value |
| --- |
| PCE | 7.02% |
| PCE | 5.22% |
| PCE | 4.23% |
| V OC | - |
| J SC | - |
| FF | - |
| band-gap | low |
| HOMO energy level | low-lying |
| crystallinity | high |
| charge transporting characteristics | efficient |

Note:

* PCE stands for Power Conversion Efficiency
* V OC stands for Open-Circuit Voltage
* J SC stands for Short-Circuit Current
* FF stands for Fill Factor
* band-gap refers to the energy gap between the HOMO (highest occupied molecular orbital) and LUMO (lowest unoccupied molecular orbital) of a material
* HOMO energy level refers to the energy level of the highest occupied molecular orbital
* crystallinity refers to the degree of order in the molecular structure of a material
* charge transporting characteristics refers to the ability of a material to transport charges (electrons or holes) efficiently

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Value of material property" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Value".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Property Value |
| --- |
| 7.02% |
| 5.22% |
| 4.23% |
| low |
| low-lying |
| high |
| efficient |

Note:

* 7.02%, 5.22%, and 4.23% refer to the power conversion efficiency (PCE) of the photovoltaic devices fabricated from PTATDPP and PTAFDPP with PC71BM and di-PBI, respectively.
* low and low-lying refer to the band gap and HOMO energy level of the copolymers, respectively.
* high refers to the crystallinity of the copolymers.
* efficient refers to the charge transporting characteristics of the copolymers.
